author: Clifford Ward
title: Woman judged insane in husband's death is committed to state facility - Chicago Tribune
text:
A Lombard woman found not guilty by reason of insanity after being charged with murdering her husband was formally committed to a state mental health center Wednesday.
At a hearing in DuPage County court, Judge Liam Brennan ordered Anka Miscevic, 50, to receive inpatient treatment at the Elgin Mental Health Center.
Brennan, following the procedure outlined in state law, ordered that Miscevic could be involuntarily committed for a period not to exceed 60 years, which is the maximum prison sentence she could have received had she been found guilty of murdering Zeljko Miscevic.
Police were called to the couple's home on Jan. 9, 2014, and found them wrestling on the front lawn. Authorities said Miscevic had stabbed her husband once in the chest as he lay sleeping, and then she hit him with a bat when Zeljko, 56, tried to phone for help.
She was eventually found mentally unfit to stand trial. At an initial court appearance, prosecutors said she had been repeatedly hospitalized in the year before the stabbing for mental health issues.
In May, following a hearing, the judge found her not guilty by reason of insanity.
The court will receive periodic progress updates on her treatment, and Miscevic will be back in court next April for a status hearing. At some point, she could petition to be released from the mental health center, which would initiate a court hearing process.
She has been in custody since the stabbing and has been receiving treatment while in the DuPage County jail and at Elgin, where she was hospitalized after being declared unfit and later evaluated for treatment. Her mental health since the stabbing has "dramatically improved," her attorney, Assistant Public Defender Steve Dalton, said Wednesday.
According to the judge's order, Miscevic can be allowed unsupervised privileges at the mental health center and also can have supervised privileges off ground. Those recommendations can only come from the mental health center, Dalton said.
The Miscevics are the parents of a teenage son who is living with relatives in the Chicago area, according to court documents.
Clifford Ward is a freelance reporter.
